title: Kenya: Don't Storm Schools, Charles Owino Tells Striking Teachers
text:
Kenya: Teachers to Attend Rally By Fred Mukinda 
Police have warned striking teachers against breaking the law during demos to push the government to raise their pay. 
Kenya Police spokesman Charles Owino on Tuesday said "stern action" would be taken against protesters breaching rules governing demos. 
While police officers have been instructed not to interfere with the protests, Mr Owino said, there are also no-go zones. 
"The police is warning teachers that stern legal action will be taken against any person who shall not obey the legal guidelines that govern strikes and demonstrations," he said. 
STORMING SCHOOLS 
"For example, storming of private schools or other related institutions is illegal, storming of boarding schools where children are undertaking their studies, even public schools where children could be studying on their own, (is outlawed). Storming and interruption is illegal." 
He spoke to journalists at Vigilance House, the Kenya Police headquarters in Nairobi. 
Teachers are expected to hold demonstrations after attending a rally at Uhuru Park in Nairobi. 
"Police recognise the constitutional provision that every person has (a) right to demonstrate, to picket and present petitions to public authorities peacefully and unarmed. Equally, every person has (a) right to fair labour practices, including participation in (the) activities of trade unions," said Mr Owino. 
STREET DEMOS 
"But we must note the freedom does not extend to violence and expression of hatred. Every person is equal before the law and (has a) right to equal protection and benefit before the law. The striking teachers should know their limits." 
Teachers have been taking to the streets for the past two weeks to push the government to raise their pay by 50-60 per cent as ordered by the Court of Appeal. 
The court ordered the Teachers Service Commission to pay the raised salaries until the appeal it has filed is heard and determined. 
An attempt to challenge the orders at the Supreme Court flopped and the TSC is now seeking to withdraw its application for a review of the top court ruling. Kenya
